channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Apple fire grows to 900 acres in Riverside County, triggering evacuations
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: More than 300 250 firefighters, several helicopters and air tankers were sent to battle the Apple fire, which has burned 900 acres in the Cherry Valley area of Riverside County.
item.content:encoded: More than 300 250 firefighters, several helicopters and air tankers were sent to battle the Apple fire, which has burned 900 acres in the Cherry Valley area of Riverside County.

item.title: L.A. County reports 69 new coronavirus deaths, significantly higher than last week's average
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Los Angeles County reported 69 new deaths related to the coronavirus and more than 2,600 additional cases Friday. The state surpassed 500,000 cases.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County reported 69 new deaths related to the coronavirus and more than 2,600 additional cases Friday. The state surpassed 500,000 cases.

media:content.media:description: MANHATTEN BEACH, CA -JULY 29, 2020: Faro Tabaja, owner of Waves Barbershop & Boutique on Rosecrans Ave. in Manhattan Beach, gives a haircut to Gene Geiser of Manhattan Beach. Tabaja moved the barber's chair into the entry way to create a safer environment to cut hair due to the coronavirus outbreak. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus cases in California surpass 500,000 in troubling milestone
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: On the same day California broke a new daily record for COVID-19 deaths, a teenager in the Central Valley has died of causes related to the disease, becoming the first such juvenile death in California.
item.content:encoded: On the same day California broke a new daily record for COVID-19 deaths, a teenager in the Central Valley has died of causes related to the disease, becoming the first such juvenile death in California.

media:content.media:description: ENCINO, CA - JULY 23: EMT Travis Carr administers COVID-19 tests at Balboa Sports Center on Thursday, July 23, 2020 in Encino, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Brush fire threatens homes in Chatsworth area
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: A 25-acre brush fire threatened some homes Friday in Ventura County west of Chatsworth.
item.content:encoded: A 25-acre brush fire threatened some homes Friday in Ventura County west of Chatsworth.

item.title: Pastor says AME church struck by racist vandalism will move on as FBI investigates
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Pastor Carieta Cain Grizzell found racist slurs and threats carved into Murph-Emmanuel AME Church outside Sacramento. The FBI is investigating.
item.content:encoded: Pastor Carieta Cain Grizzell found racist slurs and threats carved into Murph-Emmanuel AME Church outside Sacramento. The FBI is investigating.

media:content.media:description: Murph-Emmanuel AME's pastor Carieta Cain Grizzell leads her church during a Palm Sunday service. Grizzell discovered racist epithets defacing the church in early July, four years after a similar attack. The FBI is investigating.

item.title: Protester had hands up when LAPD officer shot him in head with projectile, video shows
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: LAPD officer's body camera shows a man with hands up being shot in the head with a projectile as police advance on fleeing protesters in late May.
item.content:encoded: LAPD officer's body camera shows a man with hands up being shot in the head with a projectile as police advance on fleeing protesters in late May.

item.title: 31 workers at 4 Bay Area Costcos are infected by COVID-19; stores stay open
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Officials believe most of the workers contracted coronavirus in the community, not at the Costco sites.
item.content:encoded: Officials believe most of the workers contracted coronavirus in the community, not at the Costco sites.

media:content.media:description: A couple got married at a Costco in Santa Maria, Calif. Shown is a Costco Wholesale in Danvers, Mass.

item.title: After 250 years, Esselen Tribe regains a piece of its ancestral homeland
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith, Kristi Sturgill
item.description: A $4.5-million land deal, brokered by Portland-based environmental group Western Rivers Conservancy, will transfer a 1,199-acre parcel of wilderness along the Little Sur River to the tribe in the name of conservation and cultural resilience.
item.content:encoded: A $4.5-million land deal, brokered by Portland-based environmental group Western Rivers Conservancy, will transfer a 1,199-acre parcel of wilderness along the Little Sur River to the tribe in the name of conservation and cultural resilience.

media:content.media:description: This undated photo provided by the Western Rivers Conservancy shows lupines on the Adler Ranch in Big Sur on the coast of California south of Monterey. A Native American tribe has reclaimed a small part of ancestral lands on California's Big Sur coast that were lost to Spanish colonial settlement nearly 250 years ago. The Mercury News reports the Esselen Tribe of Monterey County closed escrow on 1,199 acres about 5 miles inland from the ocean that was part of a $4.5 million deal involving the state and the Western Rivers Conservancy. It marks the first restoration of any lands to the tribe. The land encompasses old-growth redwoods, oak woodlands, meadows and endangered steelhead trout. (Doug Steakley/Western Rivers Conservancy via AP)

item.title: 1 Marine dead, 8 troops missing after training accident off Southern California coast
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: An amphibious assault vehicle carrying 15 Marines and one Navy sailor began to take on water during a training exercise, the Marine Corps says.
item.content:encoded: An amphibious assault vehicle carrying 15 Marines and one Navy sailor began to take on water during a training exercise, the Marine Corps says.

media:content.media:description: San Clemente Island, viewed from a shuttle aircraft that regularly flies military and civilian personnel to the U.S. Navy-owned land mass 68 miles from San Diego. The military airstrip is seen at the northern end. The southern end has the only remaining ship-to-shore bombardment range in the U.S. The Navy has supported an extensive ecological restoration of endangered plants and animals on the island. [For the record, July 24, 2013: An earlier version of this caption incorrectly said the military airstrip was at the southern end of the island, and the bombardment range to the north.]

item.title: As COVID-19 cases surge, L.A. librarians join the ranks of contact tracers
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda
item.description: Librarians and other library staff in Los Angeles are becoming contact tracers.
item.content:encoded: Librarians and other library staff in Los Angeles are becoming contact tracers.

media:content.media:description: WHITTER, CA - JULY 08: Denice Nossett, one of dozens of librarians in the Los Angeles Public library system who have stepped up to do contact tracing work, poses for a portrait at her home on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Whitter, CA. Nossett is a contact tracing team leader. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fears grow that releasing thousands of California prisoners will spread COVID-19 into communities
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Richard Winton, Kim Christensen
item.description: Officials cite missteps by state prisons officials handling recent releases of inmates.
item.content:encoded: Officials cite missteps by state prisons officials handling recent releases of inmates.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -JULY 30, 2020: Roderick Thompson Sr. 35, who was released 9 months early from Avenal State Prison due to the coronavirus outbreak, is photographed outside of Union Station in downtown Los Angeles after arriving there this afternoon on an Amtrak bus. Thompson Sr. had been incarcerated at Avenal State Prison for the past 3 and 1/2 years and was released this morning. He took the train from Hanford to Bakersfield and the bus from Bakersfield to Union Station. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County's tracing team repeatedly failed to detect coronavirus outbreaks at workplaces
item.dc:creator: Melody Petersen
item.description: L.A. County's contact-tracing system has repeatedly failed to alert officials to outbreaks at workplaces, allowing COVID-19 to continue to spread.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County's contact-tracing system has repeatedly failed to alert officials to outbreaks at workplaces, allowing COVID-19 to continue to spread.

media:content.media:description: VERNON, CA -- MAY 29: Workers exit the building at the Smithfield Foods-owned Farmer John plant on Friday, May 29, 2020, in Vernon, CA. Their, 153 of 1,837 employees tested positive for COVID-19 between March and May, Los Angeles County officials said. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column One: From the staggering toll of the pandemic, a shared story of human kindness emerges
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: The stories of California's coronavirus victims are powerful reminders of the many ways a single life can touch others. "Numbers ain't people," one newspaper obituaries writer said. "You have to put a human face on the suffering."
item.content:encoded: The stories of California's coronavirus victims are powerful reminders of the many ways a single life can touch others. "Numbers ain't people," one newspaper obituaries writer said. "You have to put a human face on the suffering."

media:content.media:description: Wanda DeSelle was among the thousands in California who lost her life to COVID-19

item.description: County is examining the deaths of two employees at Mission Foods Corp. in Commerce.
item.content:encoded: County is examining the deaths of two employees at Mission Foods Corp. in Commerce.

media:content.media:description: ONTARIO, CA -JULY24: San Bernardino County Health Department LVN Elizabeth McKinnon explains how to self-swab for COVID-19 test to Glenda Guerra at a coronavirus testing site at Ontario Convention Center. Ontario Convention Center on Friday, July 24, 2020 in Ontario, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: An inmate tested positive for COVID-19. Prison staff housed him with uninfected inmates, he says
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Despite testing positive for COVID-19, Alejandro Cantu, an inmate at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison, said he was placed in a pod — a small, enclosed space where inmates bunk a few feet apart — that houses 11 other men, none of them infected.
item.content:encoded: Despite testing positive for COVID-19, Alejandro Cantu, an inmate at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison, said he was placed in a pod — a small, enclosed space where inmates bunk a few feet apart — that houses 11 other men, none of them infected.

media:content.media:description: Three federal judges have ordered Gov. Jerry Brown to reduce California's prison population by nearly 10,000 inmates. Above, razor wire obstacles sit atop a fence that surrounds Pleasant Valley State Prison in the Central Valley.

item.title: Orange County Register editor killed in alleged street racing crash
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Eugene Harbrecht, 67, was a Santa Ana resident who had worked for the newspaper since 1984. Most recently, he was the national and international news editor for the greater Southern California News Group.
item.content:encoded: Eugene Harbrecht, 67, was a Santa Ana resident who had worked for the newspaper since 1984. Most recently, he was the national and international news editor for the greater Southern California News Group.

media:content.media:description: Orange County Register editor Eugene Harbrecht was killed in a street racing crash on Thursday afternoon.

item.title: La Luz del Mundo church leader faces new rape charges
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: The state's attorney general has filed new charges against the leader of the Mexico-based La Luz del Mundo megachurch, who has been accused of raping children under the guise of his leadership.
item.content:encoded: The state's attorney general has filed new charges against the leader of the Mexico-based La Luz del Mundo megachurch, who has been accused of raping children under the guise of his leadership.

media:content.media:description: Naasón Joaquín Garcia, líder de la iglesia mexicana La Luz del Mundo, comparece el miércoles en la Corte Superior del Condado de Los Angeles. (Damian Dovarganes / Associated Press)

item.title: Hubert and Kalisa, longtime African lion partners at the L.A. Zoo, are euthanized
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: The lions, both 21 years old, were euthanized after age-related health problems began diminishing their quality of life, the L.A. Zoo said.
item.content:encoded: The lions, both 21 years old, were euthanized after age-related health problems began diminishing their quality of life, the L.A. Zoo said.

media:content.media:description: Hubert grooms his longtime companion, Kalisa in March 2018. The 21-year-old African lions were euthanized Thursday July 30, 2020 due to age-related health problems.

item.title: Lawmakers and jobless workers lash out at California's unemployment agency
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California lawmakers dismissed a plan by Gov. Gavin Newsom that would take two months to resolve a backlog of nearly 1 million unemployment benefit claims, warning at a legislative hearing that many jobless people are already struggling to pay for food and rent.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers dismissed a plan by Gov. Gavin Newsom that would take two months to resolve a backlog of nearly 1 million unemployment benefit claims, warning at a legislative hearing that many jobless people are already struggling to pay for food and rent.

media:content.media:description: Job seekers wait in line to speak with recruiters at a career fair in Ontario in September.

item.title: Evacuations ordered and Highway 39 closed as fire spreads in Angeles National Forest
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: By 4 p.m., the Dam fire had grown to 240 acres and was 0% contained.
item.content:encoded: By 4 p.m., the Dam fire had grown to 240 acres and was 0% contained.

media:content.media:description: An aerial assault on the Dam Fire on Highway 39 in Azusa.

item.title: L.A. County deputy alleges 'Executioner' gang dominates Compton sheriff station
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian, Maya Lau
item.description: The allegations revive concerns of inked deputy groups — with monikers such as the Spartans, Regulators and Banditos — operating out of several L.A. County Sheriff's Department stations
item.content:encoded: The allegations revive concerns of inked deputy groups — with monikers such as the Spartans, Regulators and Banditos — operating out of several L.A. County Sheriff's Department stations

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County Sheriff's Deputy Samuel Aldama admitted as part of a lawsuit this year that he has a skull tattoo on his calf associated with the Compton Station, where he worked. The photo of his tattoo emerged in the lawsuit. The department has a long history with deputy tattoos that officials say represent cliques that promote overly aggressive policing. NOTE: The photo is an exhibit to a motion filed in court by plaintiff Andrew Taylor.

item.title: Coronavirus outbreak at USC's fraternity row leaves at least 40 people infected
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Around 40 individuals on USC's fraternity-filled 28th Street have contracted the virus. Both UCLA and USC have reported over 150 positive cases.
item.content:encoded: Around 40 individuals on USC's fraternity-filled 28th Street have contracted the virus. Both UCLA and USC have reported over 150 positive cases.

media:content.media:description: Officers patrol the USC campus in 2012 the day after four people were shot outside a Halloween party by a young man aiming at a rival gang member.

item.title: Pasadena apartment fire that killed 4-year-old is blamed on electrical malfunction
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: A fire that left a 4-year-old boy dead and his mother and younger brother critically injured is believed to have been caused by an electrical issue.
item.content:encoded: A fire that left a 4-year-old boy dead and his mother and younger brother critically injured is believed to have been caused by an electrical issue.

media:content.media:description: A young child died in a Pasadena apartment fire on Wednesday. His sibling and mother were both critically injured.

item.content:encoded: As of Thursday evening, California had recorded at least 493,140 coronavirus cases and 9,016 related deaths.

item.title: Men are less likely to wear masks. They are also dying of coronavirus at higher rates in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Mayor Eric Garcetti said that men account for two-thirds of the virus deaths in L.A. County that have occurred outside of an institutional setting.
item.content:encoded: Mayor Eric Garcetti said that men account for two-thirds of the virus deaths in L.A. County that have occurred outside of an institutional setting.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA-CA-JULY 21, 2020: People visit the Santa Monica Pier on Tuesday, July 21, 2020. California has again reported its highest number of coronavirus cases in a single day Monday. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Pension spiking' is not protected by California law, top court rules
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Unions and public employee groups lose their challenge to the ban on 'pension spiking,' which for some created pensions higher than their salaries.
item.content:encoded: Unions and public employee groups lose their challenge to the ban on 'pension spiking,' which for some created pensions higher than their salaries.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Jerry Brown has described pension reform as a "moral obligation." Above, he outlines his 12-point plan in October 2011.

item.title: Hollywood-backed activist endangered pets by treating them with his own products, veterinarians say
item.dc:creator: Paul Pringle, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Veterinarians say animal activist Marc Ching persuaded their clients to abandon a prescribed treatment regimen in favor of products he sells at his for-profit pet food store.
item.content:encoded: Veterinarians say animal activist Marc Ching persuaded their clients to abandon a prescribed treatment regimen in favor of products he sells at his for-profit pet food store.

media:content.media:description: STUDIO CITY, CA - JULY 05: Natalia Soto, with her dog Moo, is a veterinarian who raised concerns about Marc Ching giving bad medical advice to pet owners. She was treating a dog that needed surgery to remove bladder stones. She said the dog's owner told her Ching had advised that the stones would dissolve if she gave the pet his supplements, which cost her about $600. Soto photographed at Woodbridge Park on Sunday, July 5, 2020 in Studio City, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: The Los Angeles River as you've never seen it — in augmented reality
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: "Rio de Los Angeles," a new augmented reality app, brings you the story of the river from pre-history to the present
item.content:encoded: "Rio de Los Angeles," a new augmented reality app, brings you the story of the river from pre-history to the present

media:content.media:description: A still from "Rio de Los Angeles," a new augmented reality app (AR app) tells the story of the L.A. River through a series of interactive visualizations. It was was produced by Verizon Media's RYOT studio, a lab focused on immersive storytelling, in collaboration with Vrai Pictures, a content studio and the production studio Superbright.

item.title: After missing DACA, she resented her U.S.-born siblings. Trump ruined her second chance
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo, Molly O'Toole
item.description: The lack of DACA for more than 65,000 immigrant youth is forever changing the trajectory of their lives.
item.content:encoded: The lack of DACA for more than 65,000 immigrant youth is forever changing the trajectory of their lives.

media:content.media:description: OXNARD, CA - JULY 19: Beatriz Basurto, 19, middle, of Oxnard hands food to Josefa Hernandez, right, age 70, at a food give away on Sunday, July 19, 2020 in Oxnard, CA during the coronavirus pandemic. Several organizations distributed food to mostly local farm workers and their families. Seniors arrived via scooters asking for food. Beatriz Reyes is part of a new generation of immigrants who are eligible for DACA - but left in the dark as Trump tries to end DACA again and refuses to take new applications despite SCOTUS ruling. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: It's time to chop down the 'lynching tree' from this California city's logo
item.dc:creator: Christopher Knight
item.description: Defenders of the Gold Rush-era depiction of Placerville as "Old Hangtown" say changing the logo is erasing history. They're wrong.
item.content:encoded: Defenders of the Gold Rush-era depiction of Placerville as "Old Hangtown" say changing the logo is erasing history. They're wrong.

media:content.media:description: An image of the Placerville City Logo. Credit: City of Placerville

item.content:encoded: Lucy Reyes worked at Mitla Cafe, the oldest Mexican restaurant in the Inland Empire, for 68 of its 83 years.

media:content.media:description: SAN BERNARDINO, CA -JULY25: Family and friends release balloons at the memorial service for Lucy Reyes who worked at historic Mexican restaurant Mitla Cafe in San Bernardino for 68 years. Mitla Cafe on Saturday, July 25, 2020 in San Bernardino, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

In the background stand the SoFi Stadium which is still under construction. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Magnitude 4.2 earthquake centered near San Fernando rattles Greater L.A.
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: A magnitude 4.2 earthquake centered near San Fernando struck at 4:29 a.m., followed by a 3.3 quake at 4:38 and a 3.8 quake at 6:48.

item.title: Union representing father of Andres Guardado calls on sheriff to resign
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Several advocate groups, including the Unite Here Local 11 union, are calling on L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva to step down, saying he mishandled the investigation into the deputy killing of Andres Guardado and has resisted accountability.
item.content:encoded: Several advocate groups, including the Unite Here Local 11 union, are calling on L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva to step down, saying he mishandled the investigation into the deputy killing of Andres Guardado and has resisted accountability.

media:content.media:description: GARDENA, CALIFORNIA - JUNE 21: Native American dancers along with hundreds of people rallied and marched outside the Compton Sheriffs' Office in protest for the shooting of Andres Guardado, security guard who was fatally shot by a Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy on Sunday, June 21, 2020 in Gardena, California. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California considers strict 'George Floyd' law to punish police who fail to intervene
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: After officers in Minneapolis failed to stop a colleague from killing George Floyd, California is considering a new law with tough consequences.
item.content:encoded: After officers in Minneapolis failed to stop a colleague from killing George Floyd, California is considering a new law with tough consequences.

media:content.media:description: (Los Angeles, CA) Four coffins in memory of George Floyd and others who were killed by police at 1st and Broadway streets in downtown Los Angeles on June 8, 2020. Joined by interfaith leaders, labor, people of color, immigrants, community members, and victims of police brutality, Black Lives Matter-LA is set to hold a memorial service in Downtown Los Angeles on Monday, June 8, honoring George Floyd and demanding justice for those killed by the hands of the police. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newsom announces 'strike team' for California's unemployment agency as 1 million await benefits
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Many people who lost jobs or income in California due to coronavirus say they have been unable to get the benefits for which they are eligible.
item.content:encoded: Many people who lost jobs or income in California due to coronavirus say they have been unable to get the benefits for which they are eligible.

media:content.media:description: A job seeker waits to use a phone at a career center in Richmond, Calif. Economist Jack Kyser predicts that the state's jobless rate will average 12.6% next year, but other economists call his prediction overly pessimistic.

item.title: O.C. Board of Education will sue Newsom to reopen schools
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Orange County board of education votes to sue Newsom to reopen schools. Law firm Tyler & Bursch will represent the board
item.content:encoded: Orange County board of education votes to sue Newsom to reopen schools. Law firm Tyler & Bursch will represent the board

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, MARCH 18, 2020: Spring breakers, visitors and locals walk on the pier amid coronavirus pandemic restrictions downtown Huntington Beach, Calif., on March 18, 2020. Orange County bars, breweries and wineries were ordered to close, restaurants were told to offer take-out or delivery only, and people were told not to gather to curb transmission of the coronavirus. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. council votes to resume major cleanups near shelters
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Supporters of the decision said it was needed to maintain cleanliness and keep promises that city leaders made to neighbors. Critics said it would put homeless people at greater risk during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Supporters of the decision said it was needed to maintain cleanliness and keep promises that city leaders made to neighbors. Critics said it would put homeless people at greater risk during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES CA JULY 1, 2019 -- Homeless people pack up their belongings along First Street between Broadway and Spring Street during a cleanup Monday morning, July 1, 2019. The area targeted on First Street is the sidewalk in front of a fenced-in empty lot next to a portion of Grand Park used for parking during scheduled events. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Missing a mask? One L.A. politician is ready to fine you $100
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Luke Money
item.description: L.A. City Councilman Paul Koretz is ready to fine people who go out without a mask, saying such measures are needed until there is a vaccine
item.content:encoded: L.A. City Councilman Paul Koretz is ready to fine people who go out without a mask, saying such measures are needed until there is a vaccine

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 25: People in downtown Los Angeles on Thursday, June 25, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Los Angeles County Is supposed to reach 90,000 active covid cases today and the state may reach 200,000 cases, with Mayor Eric Garcetti ca;;omg for Angelenos to stay indoors amid the surge in COVID-19 cases.

item.title: L.A. County reports 91 deaths from COVID-19, the most in a single day
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The new numbers brought the county's total confirmed infections to more than 180,000 and death toll to more than 4,500.
item.content:encoded: The new numbers brought the county's total confirmed infections to more than 180,000 and death toll to more than 4,500.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 18: A jogger wears a protective mask to protect from contracting COVID-19 while passing L.A. LIVE Thursday, June 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Gov. Gavin Newsom on Thursday ordered all Californians to wear face coverings while in public or high-risk settings, including when shopping, taking public transit or seeking medical care, following growing concerns that an increase in coronavirus cases has been caused by residents failing to voluntarily take that precaution. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Admissions scandal: Manuel Henriquez, Bay Area financier, gets six months in prison
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Manuel Henriquez, who was accused of rigging his daughters' exams and bribing a Georgetown tennis coach, is sentenced to six months in prison.
item.content:encoded: Manuel Henriquez, who was accused of rigging his daughters' exams and bribing a Georgetown tennis coach, is sentenced to six months in prison.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 3, 2019, file photo, Manuel and Elizabeth Henriquez arrive at federal court in Boston to face charges in a nationwide college admissions bribery scandal. Henriquez and her husband were charged with paying $400,000 in bribes to get their oldest daughter into Georgetown as a bogus tennis recruit in 2016. They also paid bribes to have someone cheat on their daughters' college entrance exams, authorities said. (AP Photo/Steven Senne, File)

item.title: Heat wave to bake Southern California, creating potential fire danger
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The hot spell will still bake the region Thursday through Saturday with temperatures roughly 10 degrees above normal for this time of year.
item.content:encoded: The hot spell will still bake the region Thursday through Saturday with temperatures roughly 10 degrees above normal for this time of year.

A heat wave is expected to give way to cooler temperatures in coming days. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

The students said they will all wear the same suit but will don the suit after passing thorough security. The new requirements for wearing face masks in Los Angels began Monday at LAX and on local public transit. LAX on Monday, May 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

Both were airlifted by Mercy Air ambulances to National City.(Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California Legislature to consider new tax on millionaires for schools, other services

item.description: Assembly Bill 1253 would impose a new 1% surcharge on adjusted income starting at $1 million, increasing to 3% for those who earn more than $2 million and rising to 3.5% on income above $5 million.
item.content:encoded: Assembly Bill 1253 would impose a new 1% surcharge on adjusted income starting at $1 million, increasing to 3% for those who earn more than $2 million and rising to 3.5% on income above $5 million.

Holly Mitchell, D-Los Angeles, left, chair of the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, wears a face mask while standing behind a plexiglass barrier during a budget committee hearing in the Senate in Sacramento, Calif. On Wednesday, July 8, 2020, Secretary of the Senate Erika Contreras announced that, because of an increase in coronavirus cases, the Senate would not return from its summer recess on July 13. The Assembly announced on Monday it would also delay its return after five people who work in the Assembly tested positive for the coronavirus. Speaker Anthony Rendon's Office confirmed Wednesday that number is now at six confirmed cases. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: LAPD expands community policing program, appoints Black female deputy chief
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: Amid a national movement to defund the police and reinvest the money to help Black and Latino residents, the LAPD will expand its signature community policing program.
item.content:encoded: Amid a national movement to defund the police and reinvest the money to help Black and Latino residents, the LAPD will expand its signature community policing program.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-JULY 23, 2020: Emada Tingirides, center, chats with Petra Avelar, 18, left, and Meah Watson, 18, right, at Nickerson Gardens in Watts on Thursday, July 23, 2020. Avelar and Watson are best friends who grew up together in Nickerson Gardens and through Operation Progress will be attending college on the east coast this Fall. A community policing program known as Community Safety Partnership will now have its own bureau within the LAPD, headed by Emada Tingirides, whom will become the LAPD's second Black female deputy chief.(Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.description: L.A. County officials say state lab data is incomplete and six hospitals did not provide information
item.content:encoded: L.A. County officials say state lab data is incomplete and six hospitals did not provide information

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MARCH 10, 2020: Dr. Barbara Ferrer is the director of the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health. She gives her daily update on Tuesday. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Arrest made in fatal shooting of teenage girl in Hollywood
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: An arrest has been made in the killing of a girl at the corner of Hollywood Boulevard and Highland Avenue early Sunday.
item.content:encoded: An arrest has been made in the killing of a girl at the corner of Hollywood Boulevard and Highland Avenue early Sunday.

item.title: They made a home under L.A.'s freeways. But soon they could be forced to move
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: A judge ordered officials to provide space in shelters or alternative housing for homeless residents living near freeways. But where will they go?
item.content:encoded: A judge ordered officials to provide space in shelters or alternative housing for homeless residents living near freeways. But where will they go?

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08, 2020 - - Kim M. and her dog Dee-O-G live homeless under the Santa Monica freeway along Venice Blvd. in Los Angeles on July 8, 2020. The city and county of Los Angeles plan to move people from the freeways. U.S. District Judge David O. Carter passed a landmark court order banning homeless encampments from under and along Los Angeles freeways. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Outdoor religious gatherings draw warnings and rebukes from health officials
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Cindy Chang
item.description: From Orange County to Northern California, people continue to gather for large outdoor religious ceremonies without following rules to slow the spread of the coronavirus, prompting stern reprimands from public health officials.
item.content:encoded: From Orange County to Northern California, people continue to gather for large outdoor religious ceremonies without following rules to slow the spread of the coronavirus, prompting stern reprimands from public health officials.

media:content.media:description: Hundreds gathered for the weekly Saturate OC worship event held north of the pier in Huntington Beach, on Friday, July 10, 2020.

item.title: 'Open today, closed tomorrow' is the new normal for hair, nail salons due to coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: "Open today, closed tomorrow" is the revised normal for hair and nail salons struggling to stay afloat, faced with coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: "Open today, closed tomorrow" is the revised normal for hair and nail salons struggling to stay afloat, faced with coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: FOUNTAIN VALLEY, CA - JULY 22: Travis Vu cuts a client's hair in one of two chairs outdoors in front of his TravisVu The Salon in Fountain Valley, as mandated Monday by Gov. Newsom. Vu said he could never have imagined having to move his salon outdoors to do business, but is doing his best to keep his business afloat and four employees working. He and his employees has had to cut their client load by half due to the Governor's coronavirus restrictions. Photo taken Wednesday, July 22, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California is easing its bar exam score, which critics argue fails to measure ability
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Law school deans in California clamored for years to reduce the bar exam's passing score. When the pandemic hit, the California Supreme Court acted.
item.content:encoded: Law school deans in California clamored for years to reduce the bar exam's passing score. When the pandemic hit, the California Supreme Court acted.

media:content.media:description: Law students take a practice California State Bar Exam at the University of California at Berkeley campus.

item.title: How Latino dads are using TikTok to connect with their children
item.dc:creator: Tomás Mier
item.description: Charli D'Amelio who? These dads are blasting to the top of Latinos' For You Pages with #mexicandadsbelike and other relatable hashtags.
item.content:encoded: Charli D'Amelio who? These dads are blasting to the top of Latinos' For You Pages with #mexicandadsbelike and other relatable hashtags.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CA - JULY 22, 2020: Eveli Paz videotapes her father-in-law Genaro Rangel and sister-in-law Wendy Rangel using the TikTok app while they dance to Latin music for a new fad called Latino Papas on July 22, 2020 in Santa Ana, California. The Rangels are two TikTokkers who've gone viral on the app several times for silly videos.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: They're fed up with the 'tyranny' of face masks. But Portland? That's about 'law and order'
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: Federal agents in Portland are violating protesters' civil rights. But government-overreach hating conservatives say it's "law and order," not "tyranny."
item.content:encoded: Federal agents in Portland are violating protesters' civil rights. But government-overreach hating conservatives say it's "law and order," not "tyranny."

media:content.media:description: People attend the United We Stand rally in Sacramento on July 25, 2020.
media:content.media:credit: Erika D. Smith/ Los Angeles Times

item.title: Los Angeles firefighter dies from complications of COVID-19
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: Firefighter-paramedic Jose J. Perez, a victim of COVID, was 44 and had been with the LAFD for more than 16 years, officials said.
item.content:encoded: Firefighter-paramedic Jose J. Perez, a victim of COVID, was 44 and had been with the LAFD for more than 16 years, officials said.

item.title: Los Angeles police declare tactical alert in response to protests downtown
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel
item.description: According to several media reports, demonstrators organized the protests in response to federal agents being sent to Portland, Ore., to put down nightly protests that began two months ago following the killing of George Floyd by Minneapolis police.
item.content:encoded: According to several media reports, demonstrators organized the protests in response to federal agents being sent to Portland, Ore., to put down nightly protests that began two months ago following the killing of George Floyd by Minneapolis police.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 25, 2020. Protesters link arms and face off against the LAPD in front of L.A. City Hall during a Refuse Fascism demonstration on Saturday, July 25, 2020. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County reports more than 3,600 new coronavirus cases and 53 related deaths
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel
item.description: L.A. County health officials on Saturday reported 3,628 new COVID-19 cases and 53 more related deaths, high numbers that in part reflect reporting delays in the state's electronic laboratory system.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County health officials on Saturday reported 3,628 new COVID-19 cases and 53 more related deaths, high numbers that in part reflect reporting delays in the state's electronic laboratory system.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08: EMT Miriam Yanez delivers the testing kit to drivers during drive through Coronavirus Covid-19 testing in LA County at the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in South Los Angeles on July 8, 2020 as California records its highest single-day coronavirus death toll with 149 fatalities reported. The Charles R. Drew University site has tested a large number of people from racial and ethnic minority groups that are at higher risk for poor outcomes and complications from COVID-19. Drew University on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus cases seep into the ranks of Newport Beach first responders
item.dc:creator: Hillary Davis
item.description: Newport Beach firefighters and lifeguards are among the 33,358 who have tested positive for the coronavirus in Orange County.
item.content:encoded: Newport Beach firefighters and lifeguards are among the 33,358 who have tested positive for the coronavirus in Orange County.

media:content.media:description: A city lifeguard keeps an eye on the few people on the beach next to the Balboa Pier in Newport Beach on Wednesday, May 6, 2020. The city partially opened the beaches under an "active recreational use" plan approved today by State officials.
